docs.lead_paragraph: If an apple a day keeps the doctor away, will a California roll a day keep the dentist at bay? Probably not. But there is a claim that certain compounds found in wasabi, the piquant green horseradish that accompanies sushi and sashimi, can kill the bacteria that cause tooth decay. The notion of wasabi-as-cavity fighter was developed by Dr. Hideki Masuda, a research director at Ogawa and Company of Japan, which makes food flavorings and fragrances, including wasabi flavors, but not wasabi paste.

headline.main: It Works on Sushi. It Could Help Teeth, Too.

docs.abstract: Wasabi, sinus-clearing accompaniment to sushi and sashimi, may contain compounds that help fight tooth decay; but so far work has been done only in test tubes; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Treating high blood pressure is a well-accepted way of reducing the risk of strokes and heart attacks. But now, according to a new study, it may also be a way to help prevent dementia.
docs.abstract: British researchers say treating high blood pressure may be a way to help prevent dementia in elderly people; find that mild to moderate high blood pressure appears to reduce mental awareness in elderly people and may contribute to dementia (S)
docs.snippet: Treating high blood pressure is a well-accepted way of reducing the risk of strokes and heart attacks.    But now, according to a new study, it may also be a way to help prevent dementia.

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, scientists have argued over the true identity of the endangered species known as the red wolf. The few remaining individual wolves have been called a distinct species, a mere variation of the much more widespread gray wolf species and even a hybrid between gray wolves and coyotes.

headline.main: DNA Clues Improve Outlook for Red Wolf

docs.abstract: Scientists identify a population of wolves in Canada, far from red wolf's presumed distribution in southern United States, that they say is so similar to red wolves genetically that two should be considered same species (M)
docs.snippet: For years, scientists have argued over the true identity of the endangered species known as the red wolf.    The few remaining individual wolves have been called a distinct species, a mere variation of the much more widespread gray wolf species and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Do dogs bite more often when the moon is full? Yes, says The British Medical Journal. And no, says the same journal. Two conclusions can be drawn from the conflicting reports. The first is that it must be time for the journal's whimsical Christmas issue.

headline.main: Barking by the Light of the Moon

docs.abstract: British Medical Journal publishes two studies drawing contradictory conclusions about whether dogs are more likely to bite during full moon (S)
docs.snippet: Do dogs bite more often when the moon is full? Yes, says The British Medical Journal. And no, says the same journal.    Two conclusions can be drawn from the conflicting reports. The first is that it must be time for the journal's whimsical Christmas...

docs.lead_paragraph: Bassos have the biggest mouths. No slur intended against bassos, whose deep-pitched tones usually make them instantly recognizable around an opera house.

headline.main: What a Big Mouth Means to Music

docs.abstract: Dr Marco Di Girolamo, radiologist and opera lover in Rome, examines vocal cords and shape and size of vocal tract of opera singers using magnetic resonance imaging machine, which he says provides better way to determine how to classify vocal range of opera student; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Bassos have the biggest mouths.    No slur intended against bassos, whose deep-pitched tones usually make them instantly recognizable around an opera house.

docs.lead_paragraph: Although smell is the least developed of our senses, it can have definite emotional and physical effects. Real estate agents often advise home sellers to have a pie or bread baking when prospective buyers come around. The scent of a spicy herbal tea can evoke a holiday spirit. Aromatic menthol and eucalyptus have long been used to clear nasal and sinus congestion. An aromatherapy massage left me feeling relaxed and smelling delicious, at least for a day. But are aromatherapy's extensive claims of benefits -- for everything from impotence, insomnia and infections to liver and heart disease and even cancer -- anything more than anecdotal hearsay? Only a few are supported by well-designed clinical research. Most have never been tested.

headline.main: For Aromatherapy, Big Claims, Little Proof

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on aromatherapy, which uses very concentrated 'essential' oils from flowers, leaves, bark, branches, rind and roots of plants with purported healing properties; says that while there are extensive claims of benefits of aromatherapy, most have never been tested; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Although smell is the least developed of our senses, it can have definite emotional and physical effects. Real estate agents often advise home sellers to have a pie or bread baking when prospective buyers come around. The scent of a spicy herbal tea...

docs.lead_paragraph: After menopause, it is common for women to begin taking estrogen to prevent osteoporosis, the potentially disabling disease characterized by bone loss. But should men follow suit? A new study by Mayo Clinic researchers, published in this month's Journal of Clinical Investigation, reports that loss of estrogen, the dominant sex hormone in women, also appears to play a major role in bone deterioration in men.

headline.main: Of Men, Estrogen and Brittle Bones

docs.abstract: New study by Mayo Clinic researchers reports that loss of estrogen, dominant sex hormone in women, also appears to play major role in bone deterioration in men (S)
docs.snippet: After menopause, it is common for women to begin taking estrogen to prevent osteoporosis, the potentially disabling disease characterized by bone loss. But should men follow suit?    A new study by Mayo Clinic researchers, published in this month's...

docs.lead_paragraph: A report last Tuesday in the Vital Signs column of Science Times described concerns over high school athletes' use of a protein supplement called creatine. A picture with the report, showing school football players, was published in error, in the belief that the boys were masked and unrecognizable. It was not intended to suggest that either of the players actually uses creatine.
docs.abstract: Correction of picture with Dec 19 report about concerns over high school athletes' use of protein supplement called creatine

docs.lead_paragraph: Clara Holloway's boys do not go to school anymore. Instead, they often sit at home, eating and watching television in a darkened apartment here on the South Side. They are not in school because of health problems, and because their mother does not want them on the streets of a neighborhood that local church leaders are still trying to take back from the gangs and drug dealers.

headline.main: Rampant Obesity, a Debilitating Reality for the Urban Poor

docs.abstract: Article in series The Fat Epidemic discusses rampant obesity among nation's urban poor; nutritionists say part of problem is lack of knowledge and nutrition and little access to stores with healthier foods; Dr P Peter Basiotis, economist and director of nutrition policy and analysis at Agriculture Department, says that minorities have poorer diets from nutritional point of view and that many are less physically active, creating more problems; Centers for Disease Control finds that 27 percent of blacks and 21 percent of Hispanics of all ages are considered obese, compared with just 17 percent for whites; fast-food and fatty meats prevail in many minority neighborhoods; photos; chart (L)
